on March 22, 2022 disclosing another wiper dubbed "DoubleZero" targeting Ukrainian enterprises during Russia's invasion of the country. This wiper was detected as early as March 17, 2022. DoubleZero is yet another wiper discovered in addition to previously disclosed attacks we've seen in Ukraine over the past two months, such as "

The malware first checks if the current endpoint is one of the domain's controllers. If the endpoint's name is found, the wiper simply stops executing.<crlf>The wiper begins by obtaining the following privileges on the endpoint:

It aims to overwrite all files in all drives by destroying all files in all drives except for a specific list of the locations hardcoded in the wiper. The malware intends to destroy non-system files first, then system-related files. Destroying system related files while the overwriting of other files is pending can create instability and may lead to bricking the system before the complete destruction of the user's files is completed. In such cases, it may be possible to recover the files from the disk that haven't been overwritten yet.<crlf>The system folders reserved for destruction *after* all other files have been destroyed:
Change the access control of files by giving the Local System Account (WellKnownSidType.LocalSystemSid) full control of the file.<crlf>Use one of the two wiper functions to destroy the files.

The wiper will enumerate all file paths and decide if the file is "safe" to destroy immediately i.e., not a system file.<crlf>For each file that is deemed "safe" to destroy (i.e., not in the exclusions listed above), the wiper will:
NtfsControlFile used against a file to zero it out.
This routine will use APIs such as NtfsControlFile with a control code of
The second routine used to overwrite the files is relatively simpler. It opens the target file as a FileStream and simply overwrites it with an array containing all zeros.
